awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Variability, Impacts and Extremes of the ENSO-Asian Monsoon Relationship over the Common Era
awd_abstract_narration:
The research team aims to investigate the evolution of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO)-monsoon relationship over the last 2,000 years, diagnose how various external forcings (e.g., solar irradiance and greenhouse gases) and internal climate feedbacks from the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) and the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) modulate the ENSO-monsoon relationship, examine whether the recent literature documenting ENSO-monsoon relationship changes over the instrumental period hold in the past, and generate a statistical forecast model of the Asian Summer Monsoon (ASM).
 
Both the ASM and ENSO are fundamental components of the climate system.  Investigating the variation of their relationship will deepen our understanding of teleconnections, air-sea interactions, and climate feedbacks. The paleoclimate data will serve as a testbed for the verification of current theories of the ASM thereby refining dynamical understanding.

The ASM supplies freshwater resources for nearly four billion people annually. Extreme events associated with the ASM cause and/or exacerbate floods and droughts, which have far-reaching social and economic impacts in developing countries.  Large model uncertainties, however, still exist in the model projections of the ASM.  The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is an important predictor of the ASM, yet the ENSO-monsoon relationship is not stable and exhibits substantial decadal variability.  The variation of the ENSO-monsoon relationship is likely modulated by external forcing such as greenhouse gases (GHGs) and solar irradiance but also heavily modulated by internal modes of climate variability such as the PDO and the AMO. Paleoclimate records can extend the temporal coverage afforded by the instrumental era and help address such uncertainty.

The potential Broader Impacts (B.I.) include integrating climate dynamics and modeling to refine projections of the ASM and its hydroclimate extremes, which impact the economic prosperity of nearly 4 billion people in Asian developing countries. The project will broaden diverse participation in climate modeling and climate risk research by supporting research opportunities for two assistant professors, a postdoctoral researcher, two doctoral graduate students, several undergraduate students including those from historically underrepresented groups, and outreach with K-12 students and the Girl Scouts of America.  Results from this project will be disseminated to relevant management agency stakeholders at the local, state, and federal levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Floods and droughts brought by the Asian Summer Monsoon (ASM) in particular have far-reaching social and economic impacts in developing countries. Climate model simulations predict substantial changes in hydroclimate extremes over the region. Extreme dry and hot monsoon extremes are expected to occur more frequently in the future, which directly exacerbates food and energy production. The frequency of extreme floods is on the rise in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh. It is projected that the direct economic losses due to flooding under 2◦C warming is about $50 billion per year in China and US$70 billion per year in South Asia. 

This project was motivated by the fact that our ability to predict year-to-year changes and intensity of the ASM are still limited. This is in part because the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) affects the ASM, but the connection between these two seasonal-to-interannual climate patterns is not fully understood. Thus, understanding how ENSO and the ASM are connected and how extreme weather events (like flooding and drought) associated with the monsoons will change in response to anthropogenic climate change is of critical importance for  improving seasonal and year-to-year prediction of the ASM and mitigating its associated socioeconomic impacts.

Our work used climate model simulations of past, present, and future rainfall in concert with paleoclimate reconstructions spanning the last 1000 years to provide better statistics constraining future rainfall, drought, and flood risk. Our work shed light on the tropical climate dynamics controlling the relationship between ENSO and the ASM. Some of our key findings include, but are not limited to:


  • ENSO teleconnections to the Asian summer monsoon have evident decadal-centennial variability in the last 1000 years.  During most of the last 1000 years, El Niño tends to be associated with reduced Asian summer monsoon rainfall.

  • There are consistent ocean temperature patterns associated with strong and weak periods of the ENSO-ASM teleconnection in multiple data products, which could yield prediction power (Figure 1 of this report, Hu et al., 2023, JGR-A).

  • Variations in solar irradiance modulate the strength of the ENSO-ASM teleconnection on multidecadal to centennial timescales during the past millennium. High total solar irradiance strengthens the relationship between ENSO and SASM, and weakens the relationship between ENSO and EASM.  Solar irradiance modulates the ENSO-ASM teleconnection through changes in the Western Pacific Subtropical High and ENSO event amplitude (Figure 2 of this report, Du et al., 2023, GRL).

  • The Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) exerts a more pronounced impact on Asian summer monsoon variability than the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO). By comparing different linear regression models, we find that including the PDO in addition to ENSO cycles can improve prediction of the ASM, especially for the Indian summer monsoon. Dry (wet) anomalies caused by El Niño (La Niña) over India become enhanced during the positive (negative) PDO phases due to a compounding effect (Figure 3 of this report, Wang et al., 2024, JGR-A).

  • Finally, we investigated (1) the long-term characteristics of hydroclimate extremes in Mainland Southeast Asia (MSEA) and Central Asia (CA) over the past millennium and (2) the potential connections linking extreme events in these two vulnerability hotspots of Asia (Wang et al., in revision, Nature Geoscience). 

    • The intensity and frequency of extreme dry conditions in MSEA and extreme wet events in CA during the 20th century are unprecedented over the past millennium. This suggests a clear fingerprint of anthropogenic climate forcing on water-related risks in these vulnerable regions. 

    • Droughts in MSEA are coupled with pluvial conditions in CA over the past millennium, driven by the compounding influence of large-scale variability in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. 

    • Remarkably, this wet-dry dipole pattern robustly persists from the past to the future, offering the potential to improve prediction and early warning of hydroclimate extremes in these vulnerable Asian regions.


This project supported critical professional development for 7 early career researchers, including two undergraduate student researchers and three postdoctoral scholars. In addition, the research funded by this work provided support for two major Girl Scout education events in each year of the project. In particular, Dr. Dee and Drs. Du and Wang led the Girl Scout Climate Challenge at Rice University in all years of the project, a program that teaches climate and carbon cycle to over 60 K-12 students in the Houston area (Figure 4, this report). 


To predict how monsoon rainfall could be altered by 2050 or 2100, we need reliable projections of greenhouse gas impacts on monsoon rainfall. In extension work, our findings could be coupled with hydraulic models to generate probabilistic statistics on river stages throughout the Asian Summer Monsoon to characterize flood hazard. It is our hope that with maturation, this research will enable more robust predictions of climate change impacts on the ASM region for policy makers.
